platform_news.user: Please get me some news about the platform.
platform_news.ai_response:
## News — Open Brain Platform

**Total items available:** **57**

Below are the latest 5 news items (newest first). I included titles, categories, dates, short summaries and links where available.

### 1) **Join us for hands-on tutorials and live demos**
- **ID:** **1c4fe446-c83c-4764-a341-d0cc870d252e**  
- **Category:** **Event**  
- **Created:** *2025-06-16* — **Updated:** *2025-07-04*  
- **Summary:** Announcement of the Open Brain Institute program at CNS 2025 (Florence, Italy) offering hands-on tutorials and live demos covering biophysical modeling, connectomics, morphological analysis, atlas-based cortical & hippocampal circuits, and more. Full program schedule with speakers and session times included.  
- **Contacts / Instructors:** James Isbister, Lida Kanari, Darshan Mandge, Armando Romani, Idan Segev.  
- **Notes:** Sessions are hands-on and require a laptop + internet connection.  
- [View details](entitycore://news/1c4fe446-c83c-4764-a341-d0cc870d252e)

---

### 2) **Breakdown and repair of metabolism in the aging brain**
- **ID:** **783a9989-ae2f-405f-92c0-77e2cebf4dce**  
- **Category:** **Paper release**  
- **Created:** *2025-03-25* — **Updated:** *2025-04-14*  
- **Summary:** Frontiers in Science released a comprehensive open-source model of brain metabolism integrating the neuro-glia-vascular (NGV) system. The model links neuronal electrical behavior, energy metabolism, and blood flow with ~16,800 biochemical interactions to accelerate research into neurodegenerative diseases like dementia. The full model is available through the Open Brain Institute resources.  
- [View details](entitycore://news/783a9989-ae2f-405f-92c0-77e2cebf4dce)

---

### 3) **The Open Brain Institute Announces the Dawn of a New Frontier in Neuroscience**
- **ID:** **86bd2ea7-993e-4306-9c86-7aa565c3ba94**  
- **Category:** **Milestone**  
- **Created:** *2025-03-17* — **Updated:** *2025-04-14*  
- **Summary:** Milestone announcement. (Content field is empty in the record.)  
- [View details](entitycore://news/86bd2ea7-993e-4306-9c86-7aa565c3ba94)

---

### 4) **Neurons warp space and time**
- **ID:** **ff67b304-b633-402a-b414-390da4c8c8a8**  
- **Category:** **BBP news**  
- **Created:** *2025-02-19* — **Updated:** *2025-04-14*  
- **Summary:** Article describing research (Nature Scientific Reports) on how cortical excitability compresses or stretches spike sequences (“time-warping”), affecting spike timing and order. Discusses implications for neural coding and in vivo/in silico validation using cortical models. Includes commentary from James Isbister and Henry Markram.  
- [View details](entitycore://news/ff67b304-b633-402a-b414-390da4c8c8a8)

---

### 5) **Blue Brain Builds Neurons with Mathematics**
- **ID:** **7cee6c7d-6098-43d1-955d-92aa712f9a2a**  
- **Category:** **BBP news**  
- **Created:** *2025-02-19* — **Updated:** *2025-04-14*  
- **Summary:** Article on the Topological Neuronal Synthesis (TNS) algorithm (Kanari et al.) that synthesizes realistic neuronal morphologies using algebraic topology. Enables large-scale generation of unique neuronal morphologies for simulations and disease modeling; implemented as open-source software.  
- [View details](entitycore://news/7cee6c7d-6098-43d1-955d-92aa712f9a2a)

---

Would you like:
- To see more news items (next page)?  
- The full content for any specific item above? If so, tell me which ID or title and I’ll fetch it.

## Summary — cerebellum morphologies found

I searched the EntityCore brain-region index for **cerebellum** and then listed cell morphologies within that brain region. The brain-region search returned **total_items: 2115** (multiple hierarchies/aliases). I used the Cerebellum entry with **ID: 062ebc92-cebb-498a-a76d-b5ef1baf02cf** (acronym **CB**). I then requested morphologies within that region (page 1, page_size 10). The morphology search returned **total_items: 50** (page 1 shown below). Do you want the next page?

### What I will show
Below are the first 10 morphologies (page 1) found for **Cerebellum (ID: 062ebc92-cebb-498a-a76d-b5ef1baf02cf)**. Each entry includes key metadata and a link to the Entity page.

---

- **Name:** soma_10c  
- **MType:** **CBXpu_PuC** (Cerebellum Purkinje Cell)  
- **Subject species:** *Mus musculus*  
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0  
- **Description (short):** Purkinje cell located in Purkinje cell layer; large flat dendritic tree; single long axon to white matter.

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
## Summary — Recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum

Below are recent, high-impact studies (2024–2025) that focus on cortical / cerebral neuron morphology, datasets, and large-scale morphometry approaches. For each item I include the citation, a one-line summary, publication date, and a link (DOI or article URL) where available. Images returned by the literature search are embedded when provided.

### 1) Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry  
- **Authors:** Peng et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Nature Communications, 2024-11-26  
- **Summary:** Large-scale whole-brain morphometry across modalities: annotated ~182,497 cell bodies, 15,441 dendritic microenvironments, full morphology for 1,876 neurons, and detection of ~2.63M axonal varicosities to characterize diversity and stereotypy across multiple scales.  
- **Link:** [Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6?error=cookies_not_supported&code=7bec93f7-e4da-41da-bd87-e0753db25493)  
- ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 2) Whole human-brain mapping of single cortical neurons for profiling morphological diversity and stereotypy  
- **Authors:** Han, Guo, Ji, Li, Liu, Peng, Ascoli, et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Science Advances (preprint/2025 entry shown)  
- **Summary:** Attempts whole human-brain single-neuron mapping to profile morphological diversity/stereotypy in cortical neurons; collaborative multi-institutional effort linking large-scale reconstructions.  
- **Link:** Whole human-brain mapping of single cortical neurons (Science Advances) — (URL from search results)

---

### 3) A Multi-Scale Neuron Morphometry Dataset from Peta-voxel Mouse Whole-Brain Images  
- **Authors:** Peng et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Scientific Data / Nature (2025-04-23)  
- **Summary:** Describes a production workflow and cloud-based platform to generate a peta-voxel scale multi-scale morphometry dataset from hundreds of sparsely labeled mouse brains — producing the largest multi-scale morphometry dataset to date.  
- **Link:** [A Multi-Scale Neuron Morphometry Dataset from Peta-voxel Mouse Whole-Brain Images](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-025-04379-0?error=cookies_not_supported&code=de6aece5-ab73-44fb-88ff-20087963cdfc)

---

### 4) An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex  
- **Authors:** Ecker et al.  
- **Journal / Year:** Nature Communications, 2025-04-09  
- **Summary:** Data-driven, unsupervised mapping of >30,000 excitatory neuron dendritic morphologies reconstructed from MICrONS serial-section EM. Produces a low-dimensional morphological “barcode” challenging discrete m-type classifications.  
- **Link:** [An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w?error=cookies_not_supported&code=6a1db1c7-1a44-43c4-8887-fa1063dc4e42)  
- ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 5) The human cerebral cortex morphology in neuropsychiatric disorders  
- **Authors:** G. Aquino  
- **Journal / Year:** Journal of Affective Disorders, 2025-07-15 (article preview found)  
- **Summary:** Review/analysis focusing on alterations of cortical morphology in neuropsychiatric disorders — addresses macro- and micro- morphometric changes and their clinical relevance.  
- **Link:** [The human cerebral cortex morphology in neuropsychiatric disorders](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0165032725005269)

---

### 6) Comprehensive analysis of human dendritic spine morphology and density  
- **Authors:** Henner Koch (search result entry)  
- **Journal / Year:** Journal of Neurophysiology (2025 entry shown)  
- **Summary:** Detailed quantification of human dendritic spine shape/density across cortical neurons; implications for synaptic processing and plasticity.  
- **Link:** [Comprehensive analysis of human dendritic spine morphology and density](https://journals.physiology.org/doi/full/10.1152/jn.00622.2024)  
- ![Cover image](https://journals.physiology.org/na101/home/literatum/publisher/physio/journals/content/jn/2025/jn.2025.133.issue-4/jn.2025.133.issue-4/20250317/jn.2025.133.issue-4.largecover.jpg)

---

## How I selected these
- Search focused on 2020–2025 literature and prioritized large-scale morphometry, cortex/cerebrum, and human/mouse studies returned by the literature-search-tool.
- Included dataset papers, methods/analysis papers, and reviews that specifically address neuron morphology in cerebral cortex.

## Would you like any of the following next?
- Downloadable PDFs or extracted full-text from any of these (I can fetch full text where available).  
- A curated list of morphological metrics (e.g., total dendritic length, branching patterns) reported by one selected paper.  
- Plots/figures (I can generate custom summary plots from data in a chosen paper if raw metrics are accessible).

Despite this, the core content is relevant and informative.

platform_viewing.user: what is this ? what am i looking at
platform_viewing.expected_output:
Summary — what you're looking at
You are viewing a list or collection of cell morphologies filtered to a specific brain region. The platform context shows:

Observed entity type: cell-morphology
Within brain region ID: 2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd
Within brain region annotation value: 477
This means the page is showing neuronal morphological reconstructions (digital neuron shapes — soma, dendrites, axon, measurements and metadata) that are associated with the brain region whose internal ID is 2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd (annotation value 477).

What a "cell morphology" entry typically contains
Each cell morphology record on this page usually includes:

ID and Name of the morphology entry
Species / subject information (e.g., Mus musculus)
Brain region (the region the neuron was recorded/reconstructed from)
M-type(s) or morphological classification
Quantitative measurements (e.g., dendritic length, soma size) and associated units/statistics
A short description and provenance (contributor, publication)
Downloadable assets (morphology files) and viewable visualizations
Why the brain region ID matters
The platform uses atlas-driven searches. The page is constrained to show only morphologies that live within (or were assigned to) the brain region represented by the UUID 2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd. The numeric annotation value shown (477) is the atlas annotation corresponding to that region.

Next steps I can take for you
Resolve the brain region UUID to its human-readable name and show the first page of matching cell-morphology entries (includes count, and a list of items with key metadata).
Show details for a specific morphology if you click/select one (or tell me which ID/name you want).
Download a morphology asset or list available assets for an entry.
Tell me which of these you want me to do and I’ll proceed. (I can automatically resolve the region name and fetch the first page of morphologies unless you prefer something else.)
platform_viewing.ai_response:
## Summary — What you're looking at

You're viewing a list of **cell morphology** entities for a specific brain region on the Open Brain Platform. In other words, these are digital reconstructions or descriptions of neuronal shapes (soma, dendrites, axons) associated with a particular brain region.

---

### Evidence from the page context
- Entity type: **cell-morphology**
- Brain region ID: **2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd**
- Brain region annotation value: **477**

---

### What a \cell morphology\ entry usually contains
Each cell morphology record typically includes:
- **ID** (UUID)
- **Name** / label of the reconstructed cell
- **Species** (e.g., *Mus musculus*)
- **Brain region** association (the region you are viewing)
- **Measurements** (total dendritic length, soma size, branch counts, etc.)
- **M-types** (morphological cell type labels)
- **Metadata** (contributor, date, protocol used, public/private status)
- Links to download or visualize the reconstruction (e.g., SWC files) and possibly 2D/3D previews.

---

### What you can do next
- If you want, I can fetch the actual list of cell morphology entries for this brain region (shows names, IDs, species, and key metadata). There may be multiple pages — I will report the total_items count and ask if you want more pages before retrieving them.
- If you want details for a specific entry (name or ID), tell me which one and I’ll retrieve full metadata and asset links.

Would you like me to list the cell morphologies for this brain region now?

metrics.name: Correctness [GEval]
metrics.reason: The actual output provides a comprehensive summary of what the user is looking at, including relevant details about cell morphology entities and their association with a specific brain region. However, it diverges slightly from the expected output in structure and phrasing, particularly in the way it presents the evidence and next steps. import numpy as np
import plotly.graph_objects as go

# generate 8 evenly spaced points from 0 to 2pi
x = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 8)
y = np.sin(x)

fig = go.Figure()
fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=x, y=y, mode='markers+lines', name='sin(x)'))
fig.update_layout(title='y = sin(x) (8 evenly spaced points from 0 to 2π)',
                  xaxis_title='x', yaxis_title='y',
                  xaxis = dict(tickmode='array', tickvals=x, ticktext=[f'{val:.2f}' for val in x]))

fig.show()

# return numeric lists for reference
{"x": x.tolist(), "y": y.tolist()}

neuroscientists_search.user: Can you check online who are some of the most impactful computational neuroscientists?
neuroscientists_search.ai_response:
## Summary — Highly impactful computational neuroscientists (online sources)

Below I list a selection of computational and theoretical neuroscientists that multiple reputable online sources identify as highly impactful. For each person I give a one-line summary of why they're influential and provide the source link(s) found in the web search results above.

- **Larry Abbott** — major contributions to theoretical and computational models of neural circuits and synaptic plasticity; co-recipient of The Brain Prize 2024.  
  Sources: [Lundbeck Foundation — The Brain Prize 2024](https://lundbeckfonden.com/news/pioneering-work-in-computational-and-theoretical-neuroscience-is-awarded-the-worlds-largest)

- **Terrence (Terry) Sejnowski** — foundational work in computational neuroscience and neural networks; co-recipient of The Brain Prize 2024.  
  Sources: [Lundbeck Foundation — The Brain Prize 2024](https://lundbeckfonden.com/news/pioneering-work-in-computational-and-theoretical-neuroscience-is-awarded-the-worlds-largest)

- **Haim Sompolinsky** — influential theoretical neuroscientist known for work on neural network dynamics and statistical physics approaches to brain function; co-recipient of The Brain Prize 2024.  
  Sources: [Lundbeck Foundation — The Brain Prize 2024](https://lundbeckfonden.com/news/pioneering-work-in-computational-and-theoretical-neuroscience-is-awarded-the-worlds-largest)

- **David Marr** — classic foundational figure in theoretical neuroscience and vision (listed in Wikipedia’s cognitive/computational neuroscience pages).  
  Sources: [Wikipedia — Computational neuroscience / List of cognitive neuroscientists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_neuroscience)

- **James McClelland** — influential in connectionist models and cognitive modeling (appears on lists of cognitive/computational neuroscientists).  
  Sources: [Wikipedia — List of cognitive neuroscientists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_neuroscientists)

- **Eric Kandel** — while best known as an experimentalist, his work on learning and memory has deeply influenced computational models of memory and learning.  
  Sources: [Wikipedia — List of cognitive neuroscientists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_neuroscientists)

- **David Hubel and Torsten Wiesel** — vision neuroscience whose findings shaped computational theories of visual processing (listed in cognitive/vision sections).  
  Sources: [Wikipedia — List of cognitive neuroscientists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_neuroscientists)

Notes:
- The Lundbeck Foundation press release (The Brain Prize 2024) explicitly names Abbott, Sejnowski and Sompolinsky as pioneers of computational/theoretical neuroscience — a strong, recent signal of impact.
- Wikipedia lists (Computational neuroscience; cognitive neuroscientists) collected historically influential names that are commonly cited in surveys and academic discussions.
- Other “influential” lists (blogs, aggregator pages) vary in scope and methodology; for rigor I prioritized institutional announcements and curated encyclopedia lists.

Would you like:
- A longer, sourced list (20–50 names) with short bios and key papers?  
- A filtered list focused on (a) living researchers, (b) early pioneers (historical), or (c) people working at the intersection of computational neuroscience and AI?

simulation_tutorial.user: How can I simulate on the platform ?
simulation_tutorial.expected_output:
Here is a tutorial on how to simulate on the platform, specifically for simulating a single neuron model:

How to Simulate a Single Neuron Model on the Platform
Access Virtual Lab:

From the homepage, click the "Go to Virtual Lab" button.
Manage Projects:

Click on "Projects" in the left menu to see your projects.
Create a project if none exists.
Ensure you have credits in your project; transfer credits from your virtual lab if needed.
Build a Single Neuron Model:

Click on the "Build" column in the left panel.
Click the "Build" button in the single neuron tile.
Name your model, optionally add a description.
Select the brain region (e.g., primary somatosensory area).
Click "Start building."
Select a 3D reconstructed morphology (M model) and an existing electrical model (E model).
Filter morphologies by type (e.g., L5 TPC-A for thick tufted layer 5 pyramidal neuron).
Select the appropriate E model matching the morphology.
Save the created morph-electric model (M E model).
Simulate the Neuron Model:

Go back to your project homepage.
Click on the "Simulate" tab, then "Single Neuron."
Find your neuron model or search by name.
Click your model and press "New Simulation."
In the simulation window, pan, rotate, and zoom the neuron morphology.
Set experiment and simulation parameters.
Choose predefined current injection protocols or customize current steps.
Add multiple recording locations by clicking on the morphology or using the "Add Recording" button.
Press "Simulate" to run the simulation.
View and Save Results:

The "Results" tab will display recordings from selected locations.
Save recordings or save them to the library for later access.
You can watch the full tutorial video here:
How to simulate a single neuron model (Video)

If you want, I can guide you through any specific step or help you start a simulation on the platform.
simulation_tutorial.ai_response:
## How to simulate on the Open Brain Platform

Below is a concise, step-by-step guide for running simulations on the platform, with links to the official tutorials. If you want, I can open any of the tutorial videos or walk you through a specific simulation type interactively.

### Quick overview (workflow)
1. **Create a Virtual Lab and Project**
   - Create a Virtual Lab (admin email verification required).
   - Create one or more Projects inside your Virtual Lab.
   - Add credits to your Project (transfer from Virtual Lab credit balance).

2. **Build or select a model**
   - For single-neuron work: build an M-E model by selecting a morphology (M model) and an electrical model (E model). Save as an ME-model.
   - For other scales (synaptome, microcircuit, region, etc.) choose or build the appropriate circuit components (morphologies, e-models, connectivity, synapses, etc.).

3. **Prepare the simulation**
   - Go to your Project → Simulate.
   - Choose the simulation type (Single Neuron, Synaptome, Microcircuit, Region, System, Whole-brain depending on availability and credits).
   - Select the model(s) to simulate, set experimental protocol (stimuli, current injections, network inputs), and choose recording locations/variables.
   - Configure simulation parameters (duration, time step, seed/randomization, parallelization if available).

4. **Run the simulation**
   - Submit the simulation. It consumes credits from the selected Project.
   - Monitor status (created → pending → running → done / error).

5. **Inspect and save results**
   - Open the Results tab to view traces, spiking, voltages, synaptic events, population measures, or derived metrics.
   - Save recordings or export data to your Project library for later analysis or reuse.

6. **Iterate**
   - Modify model parameters or protocols and re-run as needed.
   - Use saved simulations as templates for batch runs or parameter sweeps.

---

### Official tutorial videos (from platform)
- **How to explore** — Overview of browsing data and models.  
  [How to explore (video)](https://player.vimeo.com/progressive_redirect/playback/1086317704/rendition/2160p/file.mp4?loc=external&log_user=0&signature=a48bdfd7c6ed6c7fd9ac34c62b5d901cbb591f8ea2ed3521848ed097a08ed83a)

- **How to get started** — Create Virtual Lab, Project, and transfer credits.  
  [How to get started (video)](https://player.vimeo.com/progressive_redirect/playback/1086084238/rendition/1080p/file.mp4?loc=external&log_user=0&signature=75d9815793616bde14f32a62c1a0308a68c6ba1937a3563d3e62f276fc05e697)

- **How to simulate a single neuron model** — Build an M-E model and run single-neuron simulations.  
  [How to simulate a single neuron model (video)](https://player.vimeo.com/progressive_redirect/playback/1086083921/rendition/2160p/file.mp4?loc=external&log_user=0&signature=3a7aea8250d7f90f11ca86e4334c8ac83af938ea8bfe5f4bcaf03e7f29e588d5)

(total_items: 3)

---

### Need help with a specific simulation?
Tell me which of these you want to do and I will generate a detailed step-by-step plan or create a simulation configuration for you:
- Build & simulate a single neuron (give brain region / desired M & E types)
- Run a parameter sweep (e.g., current amplitude, conductance values)
- Create and simulate a microcircuit or synaptome
- Inspect or analyze existing simulation results

If you want me to generate a simulation JSON config for a specific circuit, provide the target circuit ID (UUID) and a full description of the final configuration you want, and I will call the simulator-config generator to produce the JSON.

metrics.reason: The actual output provides a comprehensive guide on simulating on the Open Brain Platform, addressing key components such as creating a virtual lab, building models, and running simulations. While it offers valuable details and links to tutorials, it lacks the structured step-by-step format and specific instructions outlined in the expected output.
